tit.e: Kubo (public affairs, the court, the Shogun, the shogunate)
Kubo (public affairs, the court, the Shogun, the shogunate)

sen.j: 公方（くぼう）とは、前近代の日本において、国家に関する公（おおやけ）のことを体現する方面及び国家的統治権、すなわち古い時代の天皇やその朝廷、鎌倉時代、室町時代の将軍に起源する言葉である。
sen.e: The term "Kubo" originally referred to the embodiment of public affairs in the premodern Japan or the national sovereign power, that is, the Emperor or the Court in olden times, and the Shogun in the Kamakura and the Muromachi periods.

The term "Kubo" originally referred to the embodiment of public affairs in the premodern Japan or the national sovereign power, that is, the Emperor or the Court in olden times, and the Shogun in the Kamakura and the Muromachi periods.

The term "Kubo" originally referred to the embodiment of public affairs in the premodern Japan or the national sovereign power, that is, the Emperor or the Imperial Court in olden times, and the Shogun in the Kamakura and the Muromachi periods.

sen.j: 特に室町時代の後半には、将軍の公権力の代行者として君臨した足利将軍家の一族の者の肩書きとして用いられた。
sen.e: Especially in the late Muromachi period, the term "Kubo" was used as the title of the Ashikaga Shogun Family who were dominant in exercising governmental authority of the Shogun.
Especially in the late Muromachi period, the term "Kubo" was used as the title of the Ashikaga Shogun Family who were dominant in exercising governmental authority of the Shogun.
Especially in the late Muromachi period, the term "Kubo" was used as the title of the Ashikaga Shogun Family who were dominant in exercising governmental authority of the Shogun.

sen.j: 公方の称号を公方号という。
sen.e: The title of Kubo was called "Kubo go."
The title of Kubo was called "Kubo go."
The title of Kubo was called "Kubo go."

sen.j: 沿革
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 「公方」号の発生
sen.e: The creation of "Kubo go" (the title of Kubo)
The creation of "Kubo go" (the title of Kubo)
The creation of 'Kubo go (the title of Kubo)'

sen.j: 公は中国において私を内包する観念であり、日本で言うところの民と国家を総合する意味があった。
sen.e: In China, the concept of "public" included "private," which was what we call the integration of the nation and its people in Japan.
In China, the concept of "public" included "private," which was what we call the integration of the nation and its people in Japan.
In China, the Chinese character for "ku" in the word "Kubo" included the concept of "private," while in Japan this character was used to mean the integration of the nation and its people.
sen.cmt: 「公」を "public" と書いただけではわからないため補足し、全体を書き換えました。

sen.j: 日本語ではこの意が変化し、「公」は「私」を含まない観念で国家の取り扱う領分を意味する語となり、私の対義語となった。
sen.e: In Japanese, the meaning changed such that the concept of "public" did not include "private" referring to the field that a nation should deal with, and becoming the opposite of "private."
In Japanese, the meaning changed such that the concept of "public" did not include "private" referring to the field that a nation should deal with, and becoming the opposite of "private."
In Japanese, the meaning changed such that the concept of "public" did not include "private" referring to the field that a nation should deal with, and it became the opposite of "private."

sen.j: このような観念は「五公五民」「公私混同」といった用い方にあらわれている。
sen.e: This concept appears in Japanese phrases such as "Goko gomin" (to share the total harvest of rice between public and private) or "Koshi kondo" (to mix up public and private matters).
This concept appears in Japanese phrases such as "Goko gomin" (to share the total harvest of rice between public and private) or "Koshi kondo" (to mix up public and private matters).
This concept appears in Japanese phrases such as "Goko gomin" (to share the total harvest of rice between public and private, 50% each) or "Koshi kondo" (to mix up public and private matters).

sen.j: このような感覚から、古代には日本という国家を一身で体現する存在である天皇を指し示す表現として「おおやけ」という言葉が使われ、天皇やその家、朝廷を「公家（こうけ）」或いは「公方」と呼称する慣習が生まれた。
sen.e: As a result, the term "Oyake" was used to mean the Emperor as the national embodiment in ancient Japan, and the custom of calling the Emperor, his family, and the Court as "Koke" or "Kubo" sprang up.
As a result, the term "Oyake" was used to mean the Emperor as the national embodiment in ancient Japan, and the custom of calling the Emperor, his family, and the Court as "Koke" or "Kubo" sprang up.

As a result, the term "Oyake" (another pronunciation of 'ku' of 'kubo') was used to mean the Emperor as the national embodiment in ancient Japan, and the custom of calling the Emperor, his family, and the Court as "Koke" (literally, public family) or "Kubo" sprang up.
sen.cmt: "Oyake"、"Koke"に補足しましたのでご確認願います

sen.j: 特に荘園などの私的な所領が広がりを見せた平安時代後期以後には国家的な統治権を強調するためにも用いられた。
sen.e: After the late Heian period in which private fiefs like "Shoen" (manors) were remarkably spreading, the term "Kubo" was used to emphasize the national sovereignty.
After the late Heian period in which private fiefs like "Shoen" (manors) were remarkably spreading, the term "Kubo" was used to emphasize the national sovereignty.
After the late Heian period in which private fiefs like shoen (manor in medieval Japan) were remarkably spreading, the term "Kubo" was used to emphasize the national sovereignty.

sen.j: だが、相対的な朝廷権力の低下した鎌倉時代以後には、荘園・公領の一円支配を実現させた本所（寺社・公家）や武家などが、その土地の統治権の保持者として「公方」と名乗る例も登場した。
sen.e: However, after the Kamakura period when the Court's power had relatively fallen, there were some cases that "Honjo" (temples, shrines, and court nobles) and samurai families, which had achieved control of the entire manors and the public demesne, called themselves "Kubo" as the holder of the sovereign power in fiefs.

However, after the Kamakura period when the Court's power had relatively fallen, there were some cases that "Honjo" (temples, shrines, and court nobles) and samurai families, which had achieved control of the entire manors and the public demesne, called themselves "Kubo" as the holder of the sovereign power in fiefs.

However, after the Kamakura period when the Court's power had relatively fallen, there were some cases that "Honjo" (temples, shrines, and court nobles) and samurai families, which had achieved control of the entire shoen and Koryo (an Imperial demesne), called themselves "Kubo" as the holder of the sovereign power in the fiefs.
sen.cmt: 荘園・公領の定訳fiefs→the fiefs

sen.j: 更に鎌倉幕府においても弘安6年（1283年）頃より、執権北条氏の得宗・御内人・御内御領に対抗して、皇族将軍を「公方」・御家人を「公方人々」・関東御領を「公方御領」と呼称する規定が成立する。
sen.e: In the Kamakura shogunate from about 1283, the rule of namig the Shogun from the Imperial family as "Kubo," "Gokenin" (the immediate vassal of the Shogun) as "Kubo no hitobito 公方人々," and "Kanto Goryo" (the Shogun's demesne) as "Kubo Goryo" was adopted in consideration of such names as "Tokuso" (heads of the Hojo regency), "Miuchibito" (the immediate vassal of the Hojo regency), and "Miuchi Goryo" (Tokuso's demesne) in the Hojo regency.
sen.cmt: 「公方人々」の読み方を国史大辞典[吉川弘文館],古文書用字用語大事典[往来社]日本史大辞典[平凡社]などで調べましたが、わかりませんでした。
sen.e: In the Kamakura shogunate from about 1283, the rule of naming the Shogun from the Imperial family as "Kubo," "Gokenin" (the immediate vassal of the Shogun) as "Kubo no hitobito 公方人々," and "Kanto Goryo" (the Shogun's demesne) as "Kubo Goryo" was adopted in consideration of such names as "Tokuso" (heads of the Hojo regency), "Miuchibito" (the immediate vassal of the Hojo regency), and "Miuchi Goryo" (Tokuso's demesne) in the Hojo regency.

In the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) from about 1283, the rule of naming the Shogun from the Imperial family as "Kubo," "Gokenin" (an immediate vassal of the shogunate in the Kamakura and Muromachi through Edo periods) as "Kubo no hitobito" (Kubo people), and "Kanto Goryo" (the Shogun's demesne) as "Kubo Goryo" was adopted in consideration of such names as Tokuso (the patrimonial head of the main branch of the Hojo clan), Miuchibito (private vassals of the tokuso), and "Miuchi Goryo" (Tokuso's demesne) in the Hojo regency.
sen.cmt: 幕府、御家人、得宗、御内人の定訳公方人々→Kubo people

sen.j: これは皇族将軍と執権北条時宗を擁して幕政改革に乗り出した安達泰盛が採用したといわれている。
sen.e: This rule was introduced by Yasumori ADACHI, who carried out a reform of the shogunal administration under the banner of the Shogun from the Imperial family and Tokimune Hojo, the regent for the Shogun.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This rule was introduced by Yasumori ADACHI, who carried out a reform of the shogunal administration under the banner of the Shogun from the Imperial family and Tokimune Hojo, the regent for the Shogun.

This rule is said to have been introduced by Yasumori ADACHI, who carried out a reform of the shogunal administration under the banner of the Shogun from the Imperial family and Tokimune Hojo, the regent for the Shogun.
sen.cmt: 「いわれている」を訳出しました。

sen.j: 北条氏の私的権力の幕政への介入を抑制するために幕府の主権が征夷大将軍とその主従関係下にある御家人にある事を示すためだった。
sen.e: It was to prevent Hojo's private power from intervening in the shogunal administration and also to show that the sovereignty of the shogunate resided in "Seii Taishogun" (the Shogun) and "Gokenin" (the immediate vassal of the Shogun) who was in master-servant relationship with the Shogun.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It was to prevent Hojo's private power from intervening in the shogunal administration and also to show that the sovereignty of the shogunate resided in "Seii Taishogun" (the Shogun) and "Gokenin" (the immediate vassal of the Shogun) who was in a master-servant relationship with the Shogun.

It was to prevent Hojo's private power from intervening in the shogunal administration and also to show that the sovereignty of the shogunate resided in Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") and Gokenin who was in a master-servant relationship with the Shogun.
sen.cmt: 征夷大将軍の定訳御家人はすでに出ているので説明を省き、" "も取りました

sen.j: 室町幕府の「公方」
sen.e: "Kubo" in the Muromachi shogunate
"Kubo" in the Muromachi shogunate
"Kubo" in the Muromachi bakufu

sen.j: 南北朝時代 (日本)、室町幕府を開いた足利尊氏は、朝廷より公方号を許されたことが、室町幕府政所執事伊勢氏の末裔にて江戸時代の旗本の伊勢貞丈の『貞丈雑記』に記されている。
sen.e: Accoding to "Sadatake Zakki" (Sadatake's miscellaneous notes) written by Sadatake ISE who was "Hatamoto" (a direct retainer of the shogunate) in the Edo period as well as a descendant of the Ise clan which served as Mandokoro shitusji (the chief of the primary executive branch of the Muromachi shogunate), Takauji ASHIKAGA, who established the Muromachi shogunate in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, was allowed to hold the title of Kubo.

Accoding to "Sadatake Zakki" (Sadatake's miscellaneous notes) written by Sadatake ISE who was "Hatamoto" (a direct retainer of the shogunate) in the Edo period as well as a descendant of the Ise clan which served as Mandokoro shitusji (the chief of the primary executive branch of the Muromachi shogunate), Takauji ASHIKAGA, who established the Muromachi shogunate in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, was allowed to hold the title of Kubo.

Accoding to "Teijo-zakki" (Teijo's memorandums) written by Sadatake (Teijo) ISE who was Hatamoto (a direct retainer of the shogunate) in the Edo period as well as a descendant of the Ise clan which served as Mandokoro shitusji (chief of Mandokoro, the Adiministrative Board) of the Muromachi bakufu, Takauji ASHIKAGA, who established the Muromachi bakufu in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan), was allowed to hold the title of Kubo.
sen.cmt: 貞丈雑記、政所執事の定訳貞丈に(Teijo)を付記shogunate→bakufuHatamoto の" " を取りました室町幕府政所執事の室町幕府の訳を追記Teijo-zakki→"Teijo-zakki"に変更しました。"the period of the Northern and Southern Courts"→"the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan)"に変更しました。

sen.j: しかし、尊氏は多分に朝廷や公家の称としての意味合いが強かった公方号を素直には喜ばなかった。
sen.e: However, Takauji was not unreservedly happy about the title of Kubo because the term "Kubo" carried the strong connotation of the Court or the court nobles.
However, Takauji was not unreservedly happy about the title of Kubo because the term "Kubo" carried the strong connotation of the Court or the court nobles.
However, Takauji was not unreservedly happy about the title of Kubo because the term "Kubo" carried the strong connotation of the Court or the court nobles.

sen.j: 尊氏は公方の号を賜ると甲冑をまとうことができないと述べ辞退するが、一旦授けたものを撤回もできず、尊氏が預かる形となった。
sen.e: Takauji refused to accept the title of Kubo, saying that he could not put on armor if he got it; however, once the title was bestowed on him, it was diffiicult to recall it; thus, the title was tentatively left to Takauji.

Takauji refused to accept the title of Kubo, saying that he could not put on armor if he got it; however, once the title was bestowed on him, it was diffiicult to recall it; thus, the title was tentatively left to Takauji.

Takauji refused to accept the title of Kubo, saying that he could not put on armor if he got it; however, once the title was bestowed on him, it was diffiicult to recall it; thus, the title was tentatively left to Takauji.

sen.j: 以降、2代将軍となった足利義詮の時代になっても用いられることはなかった。
sen.e: Since then, the title of Kubo had never been employed even at the time of Yoshiakira ASHIKAGA, the second Shogun.
Since then, the title of Kubo had never been employed even at the time of Yoshiakira ASHIKAGA, the second Shogun.
Subsequently, the title of Kubo was not employed even at the time of Yoshiakira ASHIKAGA, the second Shogun.
sen.cmt: had never been→was notSince then→Subsequently結局、三代将軍からは用いられるので、had never は強すぎると思います。

sen.j: しかし、3代将軍足利義満以降、将軍の敬称として公方号が積極的に称されることとなった。
sen.e: However, after the time of Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA, the third Shogun, the title of Kubo was positively used as an honorific for the Shogun.
However, after the time of Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA, the third Shogun, the title of Kubo was positively used as an honorific for the Shogun.
However, after the time of Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA, the third Shogun, the title of Kubo was positively used as an honorific for the Shogun.

sen.j: 当初、関東管領としてあった足利基氏も将軍家が公方を称するようになると、鎌倉公方と称するようになった。
sen.e: After the Shogun Family called themselves Kubo, Motouji ASHIKAGA, who was "Kanto kanrei" (the shogunal deputy for the Kanto region) at first, began to name himself Kamakura Kubo.
After the Shogun Family called themselves Kubo, Motouji ASHIKAGA, who was "Kanto kanrei" (the shogunal deputy for the Kanto region) at first, began to name himself Kamakura Kubo.
After the Shogun Family called themselves Kubo, Motouji ASHIKAGA, who was Kanto kanrei (the shogunal deputy for the Kanto region) at first, began to name himself Kamakura Kubo.

sen.j: 以降、幕府の主宰者たる将軍や、鎌倉公方を称した鎌倉の足利一族により公方号が世襲されることとなる。
sen.e: Since then, the title of Kubo had been handed down for generations by the Shogun who headed the shogunate and by the families of the Ashikaga clan in Kamakura who called themselves "Kamakura Kubo."
Since then, the title of Kubo had been handed down for generations by the Shogun who headed the shogunate and by the families of the Ashikaga clan in Kamakura who called themselves "Kamakura Kubo."
Since then, the title of Kubo had been handed down for generations by the Shogun who headed the shogunate and by the families of the Ashikaga clan in Kamakura who called themselves Kamakura Kubo.

sen.j: なお、関東管領職は、それまで執事であった上杉氏や畠山氏が繰り上がって管領を称するようになる。
sen.e: In addition, the Uesugi clan and the Hatakeyama clan who had been Shitsuji (the Shogun's assistant) were moved up to Kanto Kanrei (the shogunal deputy for the Kanto region).
In addition, the Uesugi clan and the Hatakeyama clan who had been Shitsuji (the Shogun's assistant) were moved up to Kanto Kanrei (the shogunal deputy for the Kanto region).
In addition, the Uesugi clan and the Hatakeyama clan who had been Shitsuji (the Shogun's assistant) were moved up to Kanto Kanrei.
sen.cmt: 関東管領は既に出ているので説明を省きました

sen.j: 後に上杉謙信がこの名籍を継ぎ、北条氏綱・滝川一益も名乗ったという説がある。
sen.e: Some say that Kenshin UESUGI succeeded to the title, or Ujitsuna HOJO and Ichimasu TAKIGAWA referred to themselves as Kubo.
Some say that Kenshin UESUGI succeeded to the title, or Ujitsuna HOJO and Ichimasu TAKIGAWA referred to themselves as Kubo.
Some say that Kenshin UESUGI succeeded to the position of Kanto Kanrei, and that Ujitsuna HOJO and Ichimasu TAKIGAWA adopted the title Kanto Kanrei some time later.
sen.cmt: 原文の句点は振り間違いで、後に上杉謙信はこの名籍(関東管領職)を継いだ。北条氏綱・滝川一益も(関東管領職を)名乗ったという説がある。と理解し、翻訳しなおしました。

sen.j: 江戸時代には王権をほぼ全て掌握する将軍の別称として完全に定着し、「公方」と言えば徳川将軍だけを意味するようになる。
sen.e: In the Edo period, the title became firmly established as another name for the Shogun who possessed absolute power; when people referred to Kubo, they almost always meant the Tokugawa Shogun.
In the Edo period, the title became firmly established as another name for the Shogun who possessed absolute power; when people referred to Kubo, they almost always meant the Tokugawa Shogun.
In the Edo period, the title became firmly established as another name for the Shogun who possessed absolute power; when people referred to Kubo, they almost always meant the Tokugawa Shogun.

sen.j: 幕府の主宰者たる武家の棟梁は、征夷大将軍を宣下されて後、敬称が上様から公方様に転化することとなり、公方は朝廷の代行者という意味が強かった。
sen.e: When the leader of the samurai family who headed the shogunate was appointed "Seii Taishogun," his honorific title of "Uesama" changed into "Kubosama"; the term "Kubo" strongly indicated that "Kubo" was a representative of the Court.

When the leader of the samurai family who headed the shogunate was appointed "Seii Taishogun," his honorific title of "Uesama" changed into "Kubosama"; the term "Kubo" strongly indicated that "Kubo" was a representative of the Court.

When the leader of the samurai family who headed the shogunate was appointed "Seii Taishogun," his honorific title of "Uesama" changed into "Kubosama"; the term "Kubo" strongly indicated that "Kubo" was a representative of the Court.

sen.j: 初代は足利基氏。
sen.e: Motouji ASHIKAGA was the first Kamakura Kubo.
Motouji ASHIKAGA was the first Kamakura Kubo.
Motouji ASHIKAGA was the first Kamakura Kubo.

sen.j: 永享の乱で一旦滅びるが復活し、5代目の足利成氏が古河に移って古河公方を名乗る。
sen.e: Kamakura Kubo was discontinued for a while due to the Eikyo rebellion, but was soon restored; after the fifth Kamakura Kubo, Shigeuji ASHIKAGA, fled to Koga, he came to be referred to as "Koga Kubo."
Kamakura Kubo was discontinued for a while due to the Eikyo rebellion, but was soon restored; after the fifth Kamakura Kubo, Shigeuji ASHIKAGA, fled to Koga, he came to be referred to as "Koga Kubo."

sen.j: 篠川公方(篠川御所)
sen.e: Sasagawa Kubo (Sasagawa Gosho)
Sasagawa Kubo (Sasagawa Gosho)

sen.j: 3代鎌倉公方足利満兼が奥州統治のため弟の足利満直を陸奥国安積郡の篠川（ささがわ）に派遣して成立。
sen.e: Sasagawa Kubo was established when Mitsukane ASHIKAGA, the third Kamakura Kubo, sent his younger brother, Mitsunao ASHIKAGA, to Sasagawa in Asaka County in Mutsu Province for governing the Oshu region.

Sasagawa Kubo was established when Mitsukane ASHIKAGA, the third Kamakura Kubo, sent his younger brother, Mitsunao ASHIKAGA, to Sasagawa in Asaka County in Mutsu Province for governing the Oshu region.

Sasagawa Kubo was established when Mitsukane ASHIKAGA, the third Kamakura Kubo, sent his younger brother, Mitsunao ASHIKAGA, to Sasagawa in Asaka County in Mutsu Province for governing the Oshu region.

sen.j: 上杉禅秀の乱以降反鎌倉府の立場をとるが、1440年（永享12年）の結城合戦で滅亡した。
sen.e: Sasagawa Kubo took the anti-Kamakura government position after the rebellion of Uesugi Zenshu, but died out in the Battle of Yuki.

sen.e: Inamura Kubo was established when Mitsukane ASHIKAGA, the third Kamakura Kubo, sent his younger brother, Mitsusada ASHIKAGA, to Inamura in Iwase County in Mutsu Province for governing the Oshu region.

sen.j: 1438年（永享10年）に永享の乱で満貞が自害したため滅亡した。
sen.e: Inamura Kubo died out because Mitsusada committed suicide in the Eikyo rebellion in 1438.

Horigoe Kubo
Horigoe Kubo

sen.j: 室町幕府8代将軍足利義政が古河公方足利成氏に対抗させるため、弟の足利政知を関東に派遣したが、箱根を越えられず伊豆国田方郡の堀越（ほりごえ）を居所としたもの。
sen.e: Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA, the eighth Shogun of the Muromachi shogunate, sent his younger brother, Masatomo ASHIKAGA, to the Kanto region to cope with Shigeuji ASHIKAGA of Koga Kubo, but he could not go over Hakone, so he settled in Horigoe, Tagata County, Izu Province.

Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA, the eighth Shogun of the Muromachi shogunate, sent his younger brother, Masatomo ASHIKAGA, to the Kanto region to cope with Shigeuji ASHIKAGA of Koga Kubo, but he could not go over Hakone, so he settled in Horigoe, Tagata County, Izu Province.

Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA, the eighth Shogun of the Muromachi bakufu, sent his younger brother, Masatomo ASHIKAGA, to the Kanto region to cope with Shigeuji ASHIKAGA of Koga Kubo, but he could not go over Hakone, so he settled in Horigoe, Tagata County, Izu Province.

sen.j: 2代目の足利茶々丸が北条早雲に討たれて滅亡した。
sen.e: Horigoe Kubo died out because the second Horigoe Kubo, Chachamaru ASHIKAGA, was defeated by Soun HOJO.
Horigoe Kubo died out because the second Horigoe Kubo, Chachamaru ASHIKAGA, was defeated by Soun HOJO.
Horigoe Kubo died out because the second Horigoe Kubo, Chachamaru ASHIKAGA, was defeated by Soun HOJO.

sen.j: 古河公方
sen.e: Koga Kubo
Koga Kubo
Koga Kubo

sen.j: 下総国古河市に移った関東公方で、初代は足利成氏。
sen.e: Koga Kubo was identical to Kanto Kubo that fled to Koga City in Shimousa Province; Shigeuji ASHIKAGA was the first Koga Kubo.
Koga Kubo was identical to Kanto Kubo that fled to Koga City in Shimousa Province; Shigeuji ASHIKAGA was the first Koga Kubo.
Koga Kubo was identical to Kanto Kubo that relocated to Koga City in Shimousa Province; Shigeuji ASHIKAGA was the first Koga Kubo.

sen.j: 当初は古河を本拠としたが、途中から後北条氏の傀儡となって居所を転々とさせられた。
sen.e: Koga Kubo established its headquarters in Koga at first, but after becoming a puppet in the hands of the Hojo clan, it was forced to move from place to place.
Koga Kubo established its headquarters in Koga at first, but after becoming a puppet in the hands of the Hojo clan, it was forced to move from place to place.
Koga Kubo established its headquarters in Koga at first, but after becoming a puppet in the hands of the Hojo clan, it was forced to move from place to place.

sen.j: 5代足利義氏 (古河公方)の死去により滅亡。
sen.e: It died out with the death of the fifth Koga Kubo, Yoshiuji ASHIKAGA.
It died out with the death of the fifth Koga Kubo, Yoshiuji ASHIKAGA.
It died out with the death of the fifth Koga Kubo, Yoshiuji ASHIKAGA.

sen.j: 後裔は、高家の喜連川氏となった。
sen.e: Its descendants became the Kitsuregawa clan of "Koke" (a master of ceremony).
Its descendants became the Kitsuregawa clan of "Koke" (a master of ceremony).
Its descendants became the Kitsuregawa clan of koke (privileged family under Tokugawa Shogunate).

sen.j: 小弓公方
sen.e: Oyumi Kubo
Oyumi Kubo
Oyumi Kubo

sen.j: 3代古河公方足利高基の弟足利義明が上総国真里谷（まりやつ）城主の武田氏上総武田氏に擁立されて、下総国の小弓城で自称したもの。
sen.e: Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA, a younger brother of the third Koga Kubo, Takamoto ASHIKAGA, became Oyumi Kubo supported by the Kazusa Takeda clan (the Takeda clan) who was the lord of the Mariyatsu Castle in Kazusa Province.

Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA, a younger brother of the third Koga Kubo, Takamoto ASHIKAGA, became Oyumi Kubo supported by the Kazusa Takeda clan (the Takeda clan) who was the lord of the Mariyatsu Castle in Kazusa Province.

Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA, a younger brother of the third Koga Kubo, Takamoto ASHIKAGA, proclaimed himself Oyumi Kubo at the Oyumi-jo Castle in Shimousa Province supported by the Kazusa Takeda clan (the Takeda clan) who was the lord of the Mariyatsu-jo Castle in Kazusa Province.
sen.cmt: Mariyatsu Castle→Mariyatsu-jo Castle下総国の小弓城で自称した→訳を追記

sen.j: 1538年（天文_(元号)7年）の第一次国府台合戦で義明が戦死したため滅亡した。
sen.e: In 1538, it died out because Yoshiaki was killed in the First Battle of Konodai.
In 1538, it died out because Yoshiaki was killed in the First Battle of Konodai.
In 1538, it died out because Yoshiaki was killed in the First Battle of Konodai.

sen.j: 鞍谷公方(鞍谷御所・越前公方)
sen.e: Kuratani Kubo (Kuratani Gosho, Echizen Kubo)
Kuratani Kubo (Kuratani Gosho, Echizen Kubo)
Kuratani Kubo (Kuratani Gosho, Echizen Kubo)

sen.j: 室町幕府3代将軍足利義満の子足利義嗣の子孫で越前国の鞍谷を居所としたもの。
sen.e: The descendant of Yoshitsugu ASHIKAGA who was a son of Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA, the third Shogun of the Muromachi shogunate, settled in Kuratani.
The descendant of Yoshitsugu ASHIKAGA who was a son of Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA, the third Shogun of the Muromachi shogunate, settled in Kuratani.
The descendant of Yoshitsugu ASHIKAGA who was a son of Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA, the third Shogun of the Muromachi bakufu, settled in Kuratani.

sen.j: 朝倉氏により、一時は、越前守護の斯波氏に代わる越前国の統治者とされた。
sen.e: The Asakura clan temporarily acknowledged that Kuratani Kubo was a ruler of Echizen Province in place of the Shiba clan who served as Echizen Shugo (a military governor in Echizen Province).
The Asakura clan temporarily acknowledged that Kuratani Kubo was a ruler of Echizen Province in place of the Shiba clan who served as Echizen Shugo (a military governor in Echizen Province).
The Asakura clan temporarily acknowledged that Kuratani Kubo was a ruler of Echizen Province in place of the Shiba clan who served as Echizen Shugo (provincial constable).

sen.j: のちには、朝倉氏の一客将として鞍谷氏と呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: Later, Kuratani Kubo was called the Kuratani clan as a general invited by the Asakura clan.
Later, Kuratani Kubo was called the Kuratani clan as a general invited by the Asakura clan.
Later, Kuratani Kubo was called the Kuratani clan as a general invited by the Asakura clan.

sen.j: 平島公方(平島御所・阿波公方)
sen.e: Hirashima Kubo (Hirashima Gosho, Awa Kubo)
Hirashima Kubo (Hirashima Gosho, Awa Kubo)
Hirashima Kubo (Hirashima Gosho, Awa Kubo)

sen.j: 公方は将軍の別称として広く使われるようになったため、時には何某公方というように、公方に揶揄や批判の意味をこめた語をつけたあだ名が庶民によってつけられて知られることもあった。
sen.e: As the term "Kubo" was commonly used as another name for the Shogun, people gave Kubo a nickname such as "So-and-So Kubo" with a twist of irony to make it widely known.
As the term "Kubo" was commonly used as another name for the Shogun, people gave Kubo a nickname such as "So-and-So Kubo" with a twist of irony to make it widely known.
As the term "Kubo" was commonly used as another name for the Shogun, people sometimes gave Kubo a nickname such as "So-and-So Kubo" with a twist of irony to make it widely known.
sen.cmt: 「知られることもあった」のニュアンスを出すためにsometimes を加えました。

sen.j: 足利義稙の「流れ公方」
sen.e: Yoshitane ASHIKAGA "Nagare Kubo" (Wandering Kubo)
Yoshitane ASHIKAGA "Nagare Kubo" (Wandering Kubo)
Yoshitane ASHIKAGA "Nagare Kubo" (Wandering Kubo)

sen.j: 有力大名に政権を追われて各地を転々としたことから。
sen.e: The name came from the fact that Yoshitane wandered from place to place because he was forced out of power by leading daimyos (feudal lords).
The name came from the fact that Yoshitane wandered from place to place because he was forced out of power by leading daimyos (feudal lords).
The name came from the fact that Yoshitane wandered from place to place because he was forced out of power by leading daimyos (Japanese feudal lords).

sen.j: 一族は阿波国に定着し、阿波公方。
sen.e: His family settled in Awa Province, hence the name Awa Kubo.
His family settled in Awa Province, hence the name Awa Kubo.
His family settled in Awa Province, hence the name Awa Kubo.

sen.j: 徳川綱吉の「犬公方」
sen.e: Tunayoshi TOKUGAWA "Inu Kubo" (Doggy Kubo)
Tunayoshi TOKUGAWA "Inu Kubo" (Doggy Kubo)
Tunayoshi TOKUGAWA "Inu Kubo" (Doggy Kubo)

sen.j: 生類憐みの令を出してイヌを手厚く保護し、そのために庶民の迷惑を招いたことから。
sen.e: The name came from the fact that he issued "Shorui awaremi no rei" (an edict against cruelty to all living things), and he treated dogs so generously that he invited the people's indignation.
The name came from the fact that he issued "Shorui awaremi no rei" (an edict against cruelty to all living things), and he treated dogs so generously that he invited the people's indignation.
The name came from the fact that he issued "Shorui awaremi no rei" (an edict against cruelty to all living things), and he treated dogs so generously that he invited the people's indignation.

sen.j: 徳川吉宗の「米公方」
sen.e: Yoshimune TOKUGAWA "Kome Kubo" (Rice Kubo)
Yoshimune TOKUGAWA "Kome Kubo" (Rice Kubo)
Yoshimune TOKUGAWA "Kome Kubo" (Rice Kubo)

sen.j: その治世に豊作と飢饉が繰り返されて米価が大きく上下したので、その統制に追われたことから。
sen.e: The name came from the fact that during Yoshimune's rule, the price of rice went up and down because of an alternating succession of bumper harvests and famine, so Tsunayoshi was always under pressure to control the price of rice.

The name came from the fact that during Yoshimune's rule, the price of rice went up and down because of an alternating succession of bumper harvests and famine, so Tsunayoshi was always under pressure to control the price of rice.

The name came from the fact that during Yoshimune's rule, the price of rice went up and down because of an alternating succession of bumper harvests and famine, so he was always under pressure to control the price of rice.

sen.j: 徳川家重の「小便公方」
sen.e: Ieshige TOKUGAWA "Shoben Kubo" (Pissy Kubo)
Ieshige TOKUGAWA "Shoben Kubo" (Pissy Kubo)
Ieshige TOKUGAWA "Shoben Kubo" (Pissy Kubo)

sen.j: 体質が生来虚弱で言語不明瞭であったことから、殿中で小便を漏らしたという噂があった。
sen.e: As Ieshige was of a delicate constitution and had an impediment in his speech, there was a rumor that he peed in his underwear within the palace.
As Ieshige was of a delicate constitution and had an impediment in his speech, there was a rumor that he peed in his underwear within the palace.
As Ieshige was of a delicate constitution and had an impediment in his speech, there was a rumor that he peed in his underwear at the palace.
